comments.body: Elon is the man. Helping the little guy to get rich. Tweets constantly about DOGE: then it makes a bunch of people rich. Tweets about his Shiba: makes a bunch of people rich. Warns people about TSLA dump: makes options traders rich. He’s a traders best friend.

TSLA? maybe

SpaceX? way ahead of everyone
This right here.  And people can't have it both ways.  Love that he can move TSLA and trillion dollar cr!pto market on Twitter but hate that he could tank them too.

That's why people like it. Volatile UP, SELL, make money. Get out before It Volatile's DOWN.

Elon's doing the same thing, the only difference is, he represents TSLA/Is so big in the public eye, that he can more or less  make it go up and down when he wants.

Everyone wants to join him for the ride and be a winner too, but some are going to lose, and the losers are the ones paying the winners.
Is that why JPMs price target is insanely low on TSLA. They BIGLY mad.

I agree with you...but the problem is that TSLA has been overvalued for almost a decade now 😂 Bought my first shares in 2013, and people said it was overvalued then, at $70 pre-split.  Too bad I resold them at $76

It’s definitely overvalued but the analysis is only telling one side of the story. Stocks aren’t purchased purely on revenue, but potential revenue. People see TSLA and want to get in on the next one. Another aspect is TSLA/RIVN isn’t looked at as a pure automotive stock, but also tech stock which have historically been overvalued.

I think burry should put 50% of his portfolio into TSLA naked shorts, and Elon should keep 100% of his portfolio in TSLA longs. Then they should sign a contract that they will both hold that position, until one or the other is bankrupt, and that person loses their Twitter AND has to ring the NYSE closing bell dressed in a rainbow bear costume.

why?  Its actively managed but one of the best fund managers out there....Cathie cuts her losers and winners(eg she's been selling TSLA as it went higher)....you're not going to get as much downside out of it as you would an individual stock(like TSLA) as she'll make adjustments when/if she has to.  its generally a bad idea to bet against a fund anyway, especially one that are active as ARK funds are....that why some who want to bet against her created their own "fund" to short so the stocks within are fixed...
The problem is he made money on shorts when Ben Bernanke was in charge of the Fed,  he should have known that under J. Pow the money printer is always on.  Should have when long on $TSLA
He should have go all in for tech and TSLA

"The stock market is by far the best place to have one's money right now and many investors are hoping for the next TSLA." 
 
It's not really hard to understand.  And it's not about being "clueless". You could make similar points about 2013 Tesla.

I've owned LCID since 23/share and fully understand what kind of "investment" it is.  And also understand the dynamics of the wider market right now.  

I'll always buy index funds, but the list of individual stocks I am confidently buying right now is very low.  Lucid is pure speculation territory but gains are gains and IMO are not easy to find right now.  

But if you're so sure that your thesis on LCID will be reflected in its share price, congrats on the money you'll make shorting it.

Lots of people seem to forget TSLA only makes money right now on selling tax credits. It’s really the only way they survived. LCID and RIVN will not get that because all manufacturers will offer enough EVS by 2025. I see this ending very badly for investors.
Yea Lucid and Rivian will go side ways but in my opinion should go down. They aren’t even close in the self driving jackpot nor do they have a energy storage division like TSLA.

> This company dead within 10 years

or sold for parts. Does it even have any IP like TSLA?

I have a CB of 71 on $TSLA and I have sold almost all of my 30 shares. I know not a lot but I only have 4 left. This market is over heated. I’ll take my profits and wait for a correction. Even if it takes a year or two.

Edit: Grammar, I’m an idiot.

Lots of pot heads discussing prices in here.

I mean, I think he's just planning to cash in, and he wants to do it without crashing the market. An irrational CEO selling stock because someone was mean to him online isn't going to make the institutional investors dump their stock as much as a CEO convinced his company is massively overvalued.

I mean… taking a company that doesn’t have a prospectus with less than 1000 vehicles delivered and turning it into the worlds most valuable auto manufacturer isn’t founding the company but you’re plain delusional if you think he isn’t the individual most responsible for Teslas success. His ability to identify and collaborate with engineers in unprecedented and this is really what has made Tesla so dominant: immense R&D spend with an engineering oriented CEO that is willing to be agile as fuck.
The "CEO Premium" is a thing, though, and everyone is aware there's only one Elon. It's hard to believe investors are expecting Elon performance from a CEO they can't even name

> what is Tesla’s lead in tech?

Battery tech, performance/efficiency, manufacturing, safety, software/OTA, DOJO chip, charging network and more.

> what makes other car companies not able to catch up.

If Tesla suddenly stops innovating, legacy auto would be able to catch up, but that’s not the case. Tesla will still be in the lead in the future. Also, VW Ceo and Ford CEO has literally been asking Elon/Tesla for help and say they can’t ignore Teslas lead anymore. Tesla is able to produce a Model 3, 3 times faster than VW can produce an ID3, and VW plan to produce cars at the same speed… in 2026.

> What makes Tesla a tech company.

If we categorize a company based on their revenue, Tesla would be categorized as an automaker today. But Tesla also happens to make and develop software such as the in-car infotainment system and AI/FSD Beta. They also design their own chips that go into their cars and the new DOJO chip.
In the future, their energy business (solar, stationary storage) could be bigger than their automotive.

At the $80k price range, you shouldn’t have to be running into these issues at all. Coworker traded in for a Lexus LS500 and he has been much happier since. Tesla is doing great things but “quality” ain’t one of those things. They are pushing numbers in production than said “quality”. Only good car Tesla is making is the model 3

>Should there be more money down required if the home you are going to purchase isn't your primary residence? Would that help to curb this trend?

There is... investment mortgages require 25% downpayment. No it wouldn't curb the trend. I can A) keep my money in the bank jerk off with it or B) use my money to borrow more money at virtually nothing.

That's the power of real estate.
Because A has a price and B's price is similar,  B isn't overpriced..... Nope, they are both overvalued to absurd levels.

No, a fully loaded semi does not drive like a regular car.  It doesn’t maneuver like a car, brake like a car, handle winds/rain/snow like a car, go over railroad tracks or under bridges like a car, park like a car, steer like a car, or anything else like a car.  The blind spots are nothing like a car, nor is the dangers created by loss of vision while performing tasks you do very differently in a car.  It will still have air brakes, requiring a CDL with special certification.  You’ll still have to log miles and sleep, pass drug and alcohol tests, conduct safety checks and pass inspections.  You’ll still need to properly balance and secure your cargo, load and unload freight, operate landing gear and perform trailer swaps.

Training time will be the same.  It’s not a U-Haul, it’s still a 53’ semi.

Software dev here. The shares they give are similar to most big tech (think FB/Snap). It’s common to give out large amounts of stock in order to recruit top talent. U gotta understand the hiring bar at Palantir is high, so why would a dev take a risk for a small salary of 120k and no reward, ya know? I highly doubt this is the reason for the low price but I’m sure it plays a very small role in the price.

"The stock market is by far the best place to have one's money right now and many investors are hoping for the next TSLA." 
 
It's not really hard to understand.  And it's not about being "clueless". You could make similar points about 2013 Tesla.

I've owned LCID since 23/share and fully understand what kind of "investment" it is.  And also understand the dynamics of the wider market right now.  

I'll always buy index funds, but the list of individual stocks I am confidently buying right now is very low.  Lucid is pure speculation territory but gains are gains and IMO are not easy to find right now.  

But if you're so sure that your thesis on LCID will be reflected in its share price, congrats on the money you'll make shorting it.

IMO VW is one of the best value stocks in the automotive sector. Their product diversity is top notch, and has an excellent EV program moving forward. The only risk I can see is Toyota beating VW to the punch in developing solid state batteries. But Toyota has a split effort with significant resources being split towards hydrogen powered research. But their current EV platform is world class IMO. 

(Based on nothing but gut feeling- I suspect Samsung will be the first to develop Solid State but I have nothing to back that up)

Diesel gate was possibly the best thing that happened to the company, because it led to VW dumping billions into green tech to fix its image. And now VW and it’s subsidiaries are (IMO) the only OEM on track to be fully electric by 2035.

I’m also a biased fanboy, but that does have its benefits of tracking its upcoming products across the entire VWAG sphere.

I think the CPUs are coming from AMD. The GPUs are probably spread out between AMD and NVDA

It's still not mainstream, the only reason you see them in big stores is because of who produces it.

It's still super niche, Steam makes their numbers public and you can see how little market share VR currently gets. Sure, some people probably just use FB's platform (we all know it's a minority), it's still super small.

VR is definitely growing at an exponential rate though, and now that I check the numbers I've got to correct myself, swap that 10 with a 5. I'd expect VR to be relatively mainstream and used by 2026~2027.

Hi.  Thanks for the write up and you rightly point to the need for excellent commercial execution

I think we should be very clear on who the peers are for $PLTR.  

In no way is $SNOW a peer. Snowflake is a next generation, true cloud database . It’s a full SAAS model and it’s extremely strong at data analytics (though it can do true database work in a pinch).   It’s a general purpose tool that’s very simple to start using and requires zero setup and almost zero support.  Competitors include Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery etc

Compare this to $PLTR which is really an analysis / data integration platform that’s highly customized to users (so far mostly government) and has historically had a huge consulting requirement to setup.  

$Ddog is also not a good comparison as it is an application, stack and now database monitoring toolset.  

So, who are the good comparisons /competitors? IBM Watson springs to mind.  But probably the best i can think of that’s publicly traded is Alteryx $AYX.  However Palantir is much “heaver” even that Alteryx

Anyone have some better comp ideas?

No. The value of SBC as a percentage of PLTR's total compensation package for its employees is a lot higher compared to their peers at FAANG.

Edit: just to be clear to the PLTR bulls, this is a bad thing for PLTR investors.
Not paying JPM is just a bad idea

> Been around almost as long as Tesla.

Tesla is 18 years old, Rivian is 12 years old.

It took Tesla 9 years to release the Model S (yes they had the roadster but that was a super low volume proof of concept). The Model 3 has only been in production for 4 years and the Model Y for less than 2 years.

Let's hope for the sake of actual people who want to LIVE in their owned home. 

Fuck anyone buying single family homes to rent out. That was never part of the American dream. Local governments need to manage such investors so they don't take over too much of the market.

> In dollar terms, investors bought a record $63.6 billion worth of homes in the third quarter, up from a revised $58.8 billion in the second quarter and $35.7 billion a year earlier. The typical home they purchased cost $438,770—5.3% higher than a year earlier amid an increase in housing prices. **More than three-quarters (76.8%) of investor home purchases were paid for with all cash in the third quarter.**

It could help at least kill off the other 23%. just to be clear investment loans already require more money down and have higher interest rates.

Also they could prevent lenders from counting potential rental income when deciding if someone can keep their current place as a rental and still buy a new property. They could also force people buying but not selling their old place to take on a way higher interest rate to keep their old place. 

Instead what they'll do is raise the SALT deduction cap and lower interest rates further. The only thing *everyone* in power has in common is that they own real estate. Bernie has like 4 properties.

I love these takes and would love a crash, but when you have 23% of investment properties bought in CASH, its hard to have a melt down.

I realistically see a correction where your Blackstone or nameless investment group snaps them up. ZIllows a great example, they whole portfolio got bought. I live in one of the named cities with the fastest appreciation, and they are literally building communities of rental homes… not you can buy and rent but a whole neighborhood of rentals.

If youre waiting for a crash to be a fhb im sorry, wish you the best 🤞🏻

No, a fully loaded semi does not drive like a regular car.  It doesn’t maneuver like a car, brake like a car, handle winds/rain/snow like a car, go over railroad tracks or under bridges like a car, park like a car, steer like a car, or anything else like a car.  The blind spots are nothing like a car, nor is the dangers created by loss of vision while performing tasks you do very differently in a car.  It will still have air brakes, requiring a CDL with special certification.  You’ll still have to log miles and sleep, pass drug and alcohol tests, conduct safety checks and pass inspections.  You’ll still need to properly balance and secure your cargo, load and unload freight, operate landing gear and perform trailer swaps.

Training time will be the same.  It’s not a U-Haul, it’s still a 53’ semi.

Tesla did 22k in 2013 and that was their ramp up process.... Lucid wants to tackle the higher end of the luxury market (Mercedes S class  9k in sales 2020 and Range Rover 14k in sales 2020) it's a single production line currently with the second being in process for first quarter. So your comments are irrational in your disgust. 

As far as over valued yes right now there isn't a single IPO and or new company that isn't over valued and or unreasonably high, welcome to the world of dreams and forecasts. 

Lucid doesn't want to ramp up to quickly like Tesla did and there are still tremendous complaints about tesla's fit and finish. Lucid is taking the German and Japanese approach to building automobiles. The ramp up will increase as demand stabilizes and their product shines. 

The Mercedes EQS is around the corner to start production deliveries also and I imagine they won't hit much more than 20k first year either. 

If you want to complain about truly over valued under delivered look at rivian. Now that's insanity but the modern world is all pipe dreams. However it shows people want change and financials will float it. Beautiful truck btw and once again will be very unlikely to produce 20k in volume first year. 

So long story short.... What's your short? .... I mean what's your point grumpy butt?

> This company dead within 10 years

or sold for parts. Does it even have any IP like TSLA?

You're overestimating how few cars Tesla actually sells and underestimating how massive the market is. By volume sold Tesla is only like the 17th biggest car brand worldwide (which is why the stock valuation makes no sense.)

Tesla may have popularized the electric car market, but they're still just a tiny fish in a massive pond. And established manufacturers still need time to ramp up their EV production and sunset their hybrid / ICE model lines. There's plenty of room for a new EV manufacturer, the market hasn't even started to become saturated with electric vehicles yet.

Although when the market is saturated, things will become very interesting. Tesla will actually have to compete on consumer sentiment and marketing. They'll probably do very badly at first because they don't have a marketing department and will have no experience with advertising.

> what is Tesla’s lead in tech?

Battery tech, performance/efficiency, manufacturing, safety, software/OTA, DOJO chip, charging network and more.

> what makes other car companies not able to catch up.

If Tesla suddenly stops innovating, legacy auto would be able to catch up, but that’s not the case. Tesla will still be in the lead in the future. Also, VW Ceo and Ford CEO has literally been asking Elon/Tesla for help and say they can’t ignore Teslas lead anymore. Tesla is able to produce a Model 3, 3 times faster than VW can produce an ID3, and VW plan to produce cars at the same speed… in 2026.

> What makes Tesla a tech company.

If we categorize a company based on their revenue, Tesla would be categorized as an automaker today. But Tesla also happens to make and develop software such as the in-car infotainment system and AI/FSD Beta. They also design their own chips that go into their cars and the new DOJO chip.
In the future, their energy business (solar, stationary storage) could be bigger than their automotive.

Regular people? What's your definition of regular people? Realize your opinion and mine are vastly different. A Camry driver pays more for a Camry monthly than a model 3 driver. 

Tesla is currently outperforming multiple of the bigs in volume (chip shortage helps, also I'd know this as fact as my SO works for the second largest by market cap and is high enough up that there isn't much we don't know of and also she drives a Tesla because her company doesn't produce a comparable vehicle within the US.) 

They also outperform in customer satisfaction by a large margin. They are still investing heavily and don't exactly have the production capacity currently to keep up with legacy automakers. However with the next phase of Gigas starting to come. Online those 7 vehicles will start chipping away fairly quickly at the legacy 20+ platforms. 

Tesla has zero marketing investments and legacy automakers have substantial marketing investments most often exceeding  1k per vehicle sold. Calling Tesla "a fucking joke" is poor taste and shows your limited understanding. Not only are they a solar company, an automotive company, an ISP, but they are also one of the most effective emotional drivers in the market. Tesla toys is a comical giant middle finger to your comment alone. They have zero intention of slowing down and you will see them evolve the market space in the next decade pretty considerably.

This is nice trivia, but there is real value to buying at the close or in afterhours. It helps you survive the PDT rule when you're getting started and don't have 25k yet. You can reserve your 3 daytrades for emergencies -  you can take cut losses fast always without being forced to spend a daytradee. 

This is probably the most threatening thing to traders just getting started. I think most losses are because people trade something with 1 daytrade or even 0 daytrades left -> then stay in a bad and worsening trade trying to save that daytrade or avoid violating PTD.

The other 2 options, only given by the original post were (1) buy at market open and sell at the end of day OR (2) buy at end of day and sell the next morning (open). Holding for a longer period of time was the undisclosed option 3. The comment is saying buying and holding (not selling) is the best way to make money most generally, aka not day trading.
MVIS—- it’s the engine behind hololense

I felt the same way about LMND and BIGC and MAXN and NKLA and CRSP and etc etc etc. It's always easy to wish having gotten in retrospect. But remember, these big players can move MUCH faster than you can and they're experts at handing bags to others.

Just stick with fundamentals and your core feeling. Would you like to hold RIVN at $165 if it were to drop to realistic valuations? And how long are you willing to hold it at $165 to recoup your loss?

Hi.  Thanks for the write up and you rightly point to the need for excellent commercial execution

I think we should be very clear on who the peers are for $PLTR.  

In no way is $SNOW a peer. Snowflake is a next generation, true cloud database . It’s a full SAAS model and it’s extremely strong at data analytics (though it can do true database work in a pinch).   It’s a general purpose tool that’s very simple to start using and requires zero setup and almost zero support.  Competitors include Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery etc

Compare this to $PLTR which is really an analysis / data integration platform that’s highly customized to users (so far mostly government) and has historically had a huge consulting requirement to setup.  

$Ddog is also not a good comparison as it is an application, stack and now database monitoring toolset.  

So, who are the good comparisons /competitors? IBM Watson springs to mind.  But probably the best i can think of that’s publicly traded is Alteryx $AYX.  However Palantir is much “heaver” even that Alteryx

Anyone have some better comp ideas?
